metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C++ Deque
C++ Deque
In the previous page, your learned that elements in a queue are added at the end and removed from the front.
content.html: In the previous page, your learned that elements in a queue are added at the end and removed from the front.

content.text: A deque (stands for d ouble- e nded queue ) however, is more flexible, as elements can be added and removed from both ends (at the front and the back). You can also access elements by index numbers.
content.html: A deque (stands for double-ended queue) however, is more flexible, as elements can be added and removed from both ends (at the front and the back). You can also access elements by index numbers.

content.text: To use a deque, you have to include the <deque> header file:
content.html: To use a deque, you have to include the <deque> header file:

content.code_html:
// Include the deque library
#include <deque>

content.text: Create a Deque
To create a deque, use the deque keyword, and specify the type of values it should store within angle brackets <> and then the name of the deque, like: deque < type > dequeName .
content.html: To create a deque, use the deque keyword, and specify the type of values it should store within angle brackets <> and then the name of the deque, like: deque<type> dequeName.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
  deque<string> cars;
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
deque<string> cars;

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
  deque<string> cars;
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
 deque<string> cars;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
  deque<string> cars;
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.text: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {} :
content.html: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {}:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
 deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Print deque elements
 for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.text: Note: The type of the deque ( string in our example) cannot be changed after its been declared.
content.html: Note: The type of the deque (string in our example) cannot be changed after its been declared.

content.text: Access a Deque
You can access a deque element by referring to the index number inside square brackets [] .
content.html: You can access a deque element by referring to the index number inside square brackets [].

content.text: Deques are 0-indexed, meaning that [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, and so on:
content.html: Deques are 0-indexed, meaning that [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, and so on:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
  deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
  "Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
  cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the 
  second element
  cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW",
"Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the
second element
cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
  deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
 "Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
  cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the 
  second element
  cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
 deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Get the first element
 cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo

// Get the second element
 cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
  deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", 
  "Ford", "Mazda"};// Get the first element
  cout << cars[0];  // Outputs Volvo// Get the 
  second element
  cout << cars[1];  // Outputs BMW
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.text: You can also access the first or the last element of a deque with the .front() and .back() functions:
content.html: You can also access the first or the last element of a deque with the .front() and .back() functions:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
 deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Get the first element
 cout << cars.front();

// Get the last element
 cout << cars.back();

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.text: To access an element at a specified index, you can use the .at() function and specify the index number:
content.html: To access an element at a specified index, you can use the .at() function and specify the index number:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Get the second element
 cout << cars.at(1);

// Get the third element
 cout << cars.at(2);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.text: Note: The .at() function is often preferred over square brackets [] because it throws an error message if the element is out of range:
content.html: Note: The .at() function is often preferred over square brackets [] because it throws an error message if the element is out of range:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a deque called cars that will store strings
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Try to access an element that does not exist (will throw an exception)
cout << cars.at(6);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a deque called cars that will store strings

content.text: Change a Deque Element
To change the value of a specific element, you can refer to the index number:
content.html: To change the value of a specific element, you can refer to the index number:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Change the value of the first element
cars[0] = "Opel";

cout << cars[0];  // Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.text: However, it is safer to use the .at() function:
content.html: However, it is safer to use the .at() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Change the value of the first element
 cars.at(0) = "Opel";

cout << cars.at(0);  // Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Change the value of the first element
// Now outputs Opel instead of Volvo

content.text: Add Deque Elements
To add elements to a deque, you can use .push_front() to insert an element at the beginning of the deque and .push_back() to add an element at the end:
content.html: To add elements to a deque, you can use .push_front() to insert an element at the beginning of the deque and .push_back() to add an element at the end:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Add an 
  element at the beginning

// Add an element 
  at the end

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Add an 
  element at the beginning

// Add an element 
  at the end

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Add an element at the beginning
cars.push_front("Tesla");

// Add an element at the end
cars.push_back("VW");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Add an 
  element at the beginning

// Add an element 
  at the end

content.text: Remove Deque Elements
To remove elements from a deque, use .pop_front() to remove an element from the beginning of the deque and .pop_back() to remove an element at the end:
content.html: To remove elements from a deque, use .pop_front() to remove an element from the beginning of the deque and .pop_back() to remove an element at the end:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};// Remove the 
  first elementcars.pop_front();// Remove the last elementcars.pop_back();

content.code:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};// Remove the
first elementcars.pop_front();// Remove the last elementcars.pop_back();

syntax_highlighting.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};// Remove the 
  first elementcars.pop_front();// Remove the last elementcars.pop_back();

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Remove the first element
cars.pop_front();

// Remove the last element
cars.pop_back();

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};// Remove the 
  first elementcars.pop_front();// Remove the last elementcars.pop_back();

content.text: Deque Size
To find out how many elements a deque has, use the .size() function:
content.html: To find out how many elements a deque has, use the .size() function:

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cout << cars.size();  // Outputs 4

content.text: Check if a Deque is Empty
Use the .empty() function to find out if a deque is empty or not.
content.html: Use the .empty() function to find out if a deque is empty or not.

content.text: The .empty() function returns 1 ( true ) if the deque is empty and 0 ( false ) otherwise:
content.html: The .empty() function returns 1 (true) if the deque is empty and 0 (false) otherwise:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
deque<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
  // Outputs 1 (The deque is empty)

content.code:
deque<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();
// Outputs 1 (The deque is empty)

syntax_highlighting.text:
deque<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
 // Outputs 1 (The deque is empty)

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars;
cout << cars.empty();  // Outputs 1 (The deque is empty)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
deque<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
  // Outputs 1 (The deque is empty)

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cout << cars.empty();  // Outputs 0 (not empty)

content.text: Loop Through a Deque
You can loop through the deque elements by using a for loop combined with the .size() function:
content.html: You can loop through the deque elements by using a for loop combined with the .size() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i = 
  0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

content.code:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i =
0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i = 
 0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

for (int i = 0; i < cars.size(); i++) {
  cout << cars[i] << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};for (int i = 
  0; i < cars.size(); i++) {  cout << cars[i] << "\n";}

content.text: You can also use a for-each loop (introduced in C++ version 11 (2011), which is cleaner and more readable:
content.html: You can also use a for-each loop (introduced in C++ version 11 (2011), which is cleaner and more readable:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
  for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.code:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
 for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.code_html:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
deque<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
  for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.text: Tip: It is also possible to loop through deques with an iterator , which you will learn more about in a later chapter.
content.html: Tip: It is also possible to loop through deques with an iterator, which you will learn more about in a later chapter.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is a major difference between a deque and a queue in C++?
content.html: What is a major difference between a deque and a queue in C++?

metadata.question: What is a major difference between a deque and a queue in C++?

options.text: A deque allows elements to be added or removed from both ends, while a queue only allows this from one end
A deque can hold multiple data types, while a queue cannot
A queue allows access by index, while a deque does not

content.question: What is a major difference between a deque and a queue in C++?

options.text: A deque allows elements to be added or removed from both ends, while a queue only allows this from one end
A deque can hold multiple data types, while a queue cannot
A queue allows access by index, while a deque does not
